title: 103_hr3464
content:
The "Comprehensive Arson Deterrence and Fire Containment Act of 1993" authorizes funds for upgrading the Modular Airborne Fire Fighting System. The Forest Service will study ways to improve airborne fire fighting response time and report to Congress within a year. Increased criminal penalties for arsonists are also included in the Act. The "Comprehensive Arson Deterrence and Fire Containment Act of 1993" increases penalties for malicious use of fire or explosives on federal property, with fines or imprisonment up to 10 years. For offenses causing over $1,000,000 in damage, offenders face fines and imprisonment of 5 to 20 years. If a person's life is endangered, penalties are also increased. If a person's life is endangered or if damage exceeds $10,000,000, the offender faces a fine and imprisonment of 8 to 30 years. If personal injury occurs or damage exceeds $25,000,000, the penalty is a fine and imprisonment of 10 to 40 years. In case of death, the offender may face a fine and imprisonment exceeding 25 years or even the death penalty. The amendment to section 844 of title 18, United States Code, states that offenders who cause damage exceeding $1,000,000 shall be fined and imprisoned for not less than 5 nor more than 20 years. If the life of any person is endangered or damage exceeds $10,000,000, the offender faces 8 to 30 years in prison. For personal injury or damage over $25,000,000, the penalty is 10 to 40 years. In case of death, the offender can be fined and imprisoned for over 25 years or life. The amendment to Section 844 of title 18, United States Code, introduces penalties for reckless conduct resulting in destruction of property or injury to others, including fines, imprisonment up to one year, or both. If imprisonment is not imposed, probation with community service is mandated. The amendment to Section 844 of title 18, United States Code, introduces penalties for reckless conduct resulting in destruction of property or injury to others, including fines, imprisonment up to one month, or both. If imprisonment is not imposed, probation with community service is mandated, ranging from 100 to 1000 hours for adults and 400 to 2000 hours for juveniles adjudicated as delinquents. In juvenile proceedings, a delinquent must spend two days in a residential institution and complete 100-1000 hours of community service for certain offenses. SEC. 5. ELIMINATION OF FIRE HAZARDS. The Forest Service will study Federal legal impediments to clearing fire hazards and report to Congress within a year. SEC. 6. DEFENSE CONVERSION FOR STRENGTHENING PRIVATE FIRE FIGHTING CAPABILITIES. The Secretary of Defense, in consultation with the Federal Aviation Administration, must report to Congress within one year on utilizing excess military cargo, other available planes, and private fire fighting contractors for fire fighting purposes. Additionally, they must propose reforms to Federal aviation regulations to maximize the use of such planes. SEC. 7. The Forest Service will study building roads and backup power supplies to ensure water availability for fire fighting in national forest areas. Results will be reported to Congress within one year.

SEC. 8. The Secretary of Agriculture will reduce below-cost direct loans of the Farmers Home Administration by 5% for fiscal years 1994 through 1998.
